Jesus! Ain't that a load off! You  live in 605?
Yeah.
How long you been up there, Fink?
A week, eight, nine days
Is this multiple choice?
Nine days  Tuesday
You know this slob? He is holding a small black-and-white photograph out towa Barton. There is a long beat as Barton studies the picture.
...Yeah, he... he lives next door to  me.
That's right, Fink, he lives next  door to you.
Ever talk to him?
...Once or twice. His name is Charlie  Meadows.
Yeah, and I'm Buck Rogers.
His name is Mundt. Karl Mundt.
Also known as Madman Mundt.
He's a little funny in the head.
What did... What did he
Funny. As in, he likes to ventilate  people with a shotgun and then cut  their heads off.
Yeah, he's funny that way.
Started in Kansas City. Couple of  housewives.
Couple of days ago we see the same  M.O. out in Los Feliz.
Doctor. Ear, nose and throat man,.
All of which he's now missin'.
Well, some of his throat was there.
Physician, heal thyself.
Good luck with no fuckin' head.
Anyway.
Hollywood precinct finds another  stiff yesterday. Not too far from  here. This one's better looking than  the doc.
Female caucasian, thirty years old.  Nice tits. No head. You ever see  Mundt with anyone meets that  description?
But, you know, with the head still  on.
...No. I never saw him with anyone  else.
So. You talked to Mundt, what about?
Nothing, really. Said he was in the  insurance business. Deutsch indicates Mastrionotti.
Yeah, and he's Buck Rogers.
No reputable company would hire a  guy like that.
Well that's what he said.
What else?

He... I'm trying to think... Nothing,  really... He... He said he liked  Jack Oakie pictures. Mastrionotti looks at Deutsch. Deutsch looks at Mastriono After a beat, Mastrionotti looks back at Barton.
Ya know, Fink, ordinarily we say  anything you might remember could be  helpful. But I'll be frank with you:  That is not helpful.
Ya see how he's not writing it down?
Fink. That's a Jewish name, isn't  it?
Yeah. Mastrionotti gets to his feet, looking around the lobby.
Yeah, I didn't think this dump was  restricted. He digs in his pocket.
...Mundt has disappeared. I don't  think he'll be back. But... He hands Barton a card.
...give me a call if you see him. Or  if you remember something that isn't  totally idiotic.

We are tracking toward the paper-wrapped parcel that sits the nightstand next to Barton's bed.    Barton enters and picks it up. He holds it for a beat, lo at it, then brings it over to the secretary and sits. He shakes it. No sound; whatever is inside is well packed. Barton holds it up to his ear and listens for a long beat as if it were a seashell and he is listening for the surf Finally he puts it on his desk, beneath the picture of th bathing beauty, and starts typing, quickly and steadily.

Some time later; Barton still types. He is face to us; be him we can see the bed with its rust-colored stain. The phone rings. Barton ignores it. It continues to ring. Barton rises and exits frame; we hold on to the bed in th background. We hear Barton's footsteps on the bathroom ti as the phone continues ringing. Barton sits back into frame stuffing cotton into each ear He resumes typing.

Barton typing. The desk trembles under the working of the typewriter.  Charlie's parcel chatters. Barton takes a finished page out of the carriage and plac it face down on the growing stack to his right. He feeds a new page. We hear the muted ding of the elevator down t hall. Barton resumes typing. We hear a knock on Barton's door. Barton does not react,  apparently not hearing.

We are close on the bottom of the door. Someone in the ha is sliding a note beneath the door; then his shadow disap and his footsteps recede. The note is a printed message headed: "While You Were Out " Underneath are the printed words: "You were called by"  and, handwritten in the space following: "Mr. Ben Geisler Handwritten below, in the message space: "Thank you. Lipnik loved your meeting. Keep up the good w Barton's offscreen typing continues steadily.

A perfectly symmetrical wide low angle shot of the empty  hall.  Shoes are set put in front of each door except for one in the middle background. At the cut in we hear faint, regular typing. We hold for a beat. There is no motion. The long, empty h The distant typing. We hold. The typing stops. There is a beat of quiet. It is broken by the sound of a door opening. It is the  shoeless door in the middle background. A hand reaches out to place a pair of shoes in the doorwa The hand withdraws. The door closes. A short beat of silence. The distant typing resumes. The long empty hall. The distant typing.
We hear the distant sound of a woman's voice, tinny and  indistinct.
Just a minute and I'll connect you...
His eyes are red-rimmed and wild. He sits on the edge of bed holding the phone to his ear. His voice is unnaturally loud:

Hello? Operator! I can't... Oh! He stops, reaches up, takes a cotton wad out of his ear. We hear various clicks and clacks as the telephone lines  switch, and then a distant ring. The phone rings three or four times before it is answered by a groggy voice.
...Hello.
Garland, it's me.
Barton? What time is it? Are you all  right?
Yeah, I'm fine, Garland  I have to  talk to you. I'm calling long  distance.
Okay. Muffled, we hear Garland speaking to someone else.
...It's Barton. Calling long distance. Back into the receiver:
...What is it Barton? Are you okay?
I'm fine, garland, but I have to  talk with you.
Go ahead, son.
It's about what I'm writing, Garland.  It's really... I think it's really  big.
What do you mean, Barton?
Not big in the sense of large   although it's that too. I mean  important. This may be the most  IMPORTANT work I've done.
Well, I'm... glad to hear that
Very important, Garland. I just  thought you should know that. Whatever  happens.
...That's fine.
Have you read the Bible, Garland?
...Barton, is everything okay?
Yes... Isn't it?
Well, I'm just asking. You sound a  little  Guardedly:
Sound a little what?
Well, you just... sound a little Bitterly:
Thanks, Garland. Thanks for all the  encouragement. He slams down the phone.
A one-quarter shot on Barton from behind as he picks up t cotton wad and sticks it back in his right ear. He resumes typing, furiously. After a beat he mutters, still typing.
...Nitwit.
Later. We hear typing and the roar of the surf.'

We are extremely close on the key-strike area. As we cut Barton is typing: "p-o-s-t-c-a-r-d-." The carriage returns a couple of times and "T-H-EE-N-D" i typed in. The paper is ripped out of the carriage.

Lying face down on the desk; the last page is added, face down, to the pile.  The pile is picked up, its edges are  straightened with a couple of thumps against the desktop, and then the pile is replaced on the desk, face up.  The  title page reads:

Motion Picture Scenario  By  Barton Fink" Barton's right hand enters frame to deposit a small cotto wad on top of the script. Barton's left hand enters to deposit another small cotton wad on top of the script. We hear Barton walk away. We hear bath water run.
Still looking out to sea.
We are booming down to the dance floor as a raucous band  plays an up-tempo number.
Dancing animatedly, almost maniacally, his fingers jabbin the air. The hall is crowded, but Barton is one of few men not in  uniform.
Giggling, dancing opposite Barton.
You're cute!
Caught up in his dancing, oblivious to the girl. A white uniformed arm reaches in to tap Barton on the  shoulder.
'Scuse me, buddy, mind if I cut in? Barton glares at him.
This is MY dance, sailor!
C'mon buddy, I'm shipping out  tomorrow. For some reason, Barton is angry.
I'm a writer! Celebrating the  completion of something GOOD!  Do  you understand that, sailor? I'm a
His bellowing has drawn onlookers' attention.
Step aside, four-eyes! Let someone  else spin the dame! Give the navy a  dance! Hey, Four-F, take a hike! Barton turns furiously against the crowd.
I'm a writer, you monsters! I CREATE!   He points at his head.
...This is my uniform! He taps his skull.
...THIS is how I serve the common  man!  THIS is where I  WHAPP! An infantry man tags Barton's chin on the button.  Bodies surge. The crowd gasps. The band blares nightmaris on.
Quiet at the cut. After a beat, there is a faint ding at the end of the hal and, as the elevator door opens, we faintly hear:
This stop: six. Barton, disheveled, emerges and stumbles wearily down the hall. He stops in front of his door, takes his key out, a enters the room.
Mastrionotti is sitting on the edge of the bed reading  Barton's manuscript. Deutsch stands in front of the desk staring at the bathin beauty.
Mother: What is to become of him.  Father: We'll be hearing from that  crazy wrestler.  And I don't mean a  postcard. Fade out. The end. He looks up at Barton.
...I thought you said you were a  writer.
I dunno, Duke. I kinda liked it.
Keep your filthy eyes off that. Deutsch turns toward Barton and throws a folded newspaper him.

You made morning papers, Fink. Barton opens the paper. A headline reads: Writer Found  Headless in Chavez Ravine. The story has two pictures  a  studio publicity portrait of Mayhew, and a photograph of crime scene: two plainclothes detectives stare down into gulley as a uniformed cop restrains a pair of leashed dog
Second one of your friends to end up  dead.
You didn't tell us you knew the dame. With a jerk of his thumb, Mastrionotti indicates the  bloodstained bed.
Sixth floor too high for you, Fink?
Give you nose bleeds? Barton crosses the room and sits at the foot of the bed,  staring at the newspaper.
Just tell me one thing, Fink: Where'd  you put their heads? Distractedly:
Charlie... Charlie's back...
No kidding, bright boy  we smelt  Mundt all over this. Was he the idea  man?
Tell us where the heads are, maybe  they'll go easy on you.
Only fry you once. Barton rubs his temples.
Could you come back later?  It's  just...  too hot... My head is killing  me.
All right, forget the heads. Where's  Mundt, Fink?
He teach you to do it?
You two have some sick sex thing?
Sex?! He's a MAN! We WRESTLED!
You're a sick fuck, Fink.
All right, moron, you're under arrest. Barton seems oblivious to the two men.

Charlie's back. It's hot... He's  back. Down the hall we hear the ding of the arriving elevator. Mastrionotti cocks his head with a quizzical look. He rises and walks slowly out into the hall. Deutsch wath him go.
Mastrionotti in the hallway in full shot, framed by the d still looking puzzled.

...Fred... Deutsch stands and pushes his suit coat back past the gun his hip, revealing a pair of handcuffs on his belt. He  unhitches the cuffs and slips one around Barton's right w and the other around a loop in the wrought iron footboard the bed.
Sit tight, Fink.
As Deutsch joins Mastrionotti.
Why's it so goddamn hot out here?
...Fred... Deutsch looks where Mastrionotti is looking.
Tacky yellow fluid streams down. The walls are pouring sw The hallway is quiet.
They look at each other. They look down the hall.

The elevator stands open at the far end of the empty hall For a long beat, nothing. Finally Pete, the elevator man, emerges. At this distance, he is a small figure, stumbling this wa and that, his hands presseed against the sides of his hea He turns to face Mastrionotti and Deutsch and takes a few steps forward, still clutching his head.
Watching.

He takes on last step, then collapses. As he pitches forward his hands fall away from his head. head separates from his neck, hits the floor, and rolls a from his body with a dull irregular trundle sound.
Wide-eyed, they look at each other, then back down the ha All is quiet.
Smoke is beginning to drift into the far end of the hall. We hear a muted rumble.
Mastrionotti tugs at his tie. He slowly unholsters his gu Deutsch slowly, hypnotically, follows suit.
... Show yourself, Mundt! More quiet.
More smoke.
The crack where the floor of the elevator meets that of t hall. It flickers with red light from below. Bottom-lit smoke s up.
Standing in the foreground, gun at ready. Sweat pours dow his face. Behind him, Deutsch stands nervously in the light-spill f Barton's doorway. The rumble and crackle of fire grows louder.
More smoke.
Sweating. A swath of wallpaper sags away from the top of the wall,  exposing glistening lath underneath. With a light airy pop, the lathwork catches on fire.
Sweating.
...Mundt!
The hallway. Its end-facing-wall slowly spreads flame fro where the wallpaper droops.

More red bottom-lit smoke seeps up from the crack between elevator and hallway floors. With a groan of tension relieved cables and a swaying of elevator door, a pair of feet crosses the threshold into doorway.

Wide on the hallway. Charlie Meadows has emerged from the elevator and is hellishly backlit by the flame. His suit coat hangs open. His hat is pushed back on his h From his right hand his briefcase dangles. He stands motionless, facing us. There is something monum in his posture, shoulders thrown back.
Tensed. Behind him, Deutsch gulps.
There's a boy, Mundt. Put the policy  case down and your mitts in the air.
He leans slowly down to put the briefcase on the floor.
Relax. He murmurs:
He's complying.

He straightens up from the briefcase, a sawed-off shotgun his hands. BOOM! The shotgun spits fire. Mastrionotti's face is peppered by buckshot and he is blo back down the hallway into Deutsch. Bellowing fills the hallway over the roar of the fire:

head_text.subj: SHOW YOU THE LIFE OF THE MIND

text: The fire starts racing down the hallway.
Fire races along the wall-sweat goopus.
His eyes widen at Charlie and the approaching fire; his g dangles forgotten from his right hand.
Charlie is charging down the hallway, holding his shotgun loosely in front of his chest, in double-time position. T fire races along with him. He is bellowing:
Terrified, he turns and runs.
As he runs down the flaming hallway, pursued by flames, s and Karl Mundt  who, also on the run, levels his shotgun.
His legs and feet spout blood, paddle futilely at the air then come down in a twisting wobble, like a car on blown  tires, and pitch him helplessly to the floor.
He slows to a trot and cracks open the shotgun.
Weeping and dragging himself forward on his elbows.
He slows to a walk.
Barton strains at his handcuffs.
Through the open doorway we see Charlie pass, pushing two shells into his shotgun.

Charlie looms behind him and  THWACK  snaps the shotgun  closed. Deutsch rolls over to rest on his elbows, facing Charlie. Charlie primes the shotgun  CLACK. He presses both barrels against the bridge of Deutsh's no
Heil Hitler.
Screams.
Tightens a finger over both triggers. He squeezes.
He flinches. The gunshot echoes away. Barton strains at the handcuffs. We hear Charlie's footsteps approach  slowly, heavily.
Charlie, walking down the hall, glances in and seems mild surprised to see Barton. The set of his jaw relaxes. His  expression softens. He pushes his hat farther back on his head.
Barton! He shakes is head and whistles.
...Brother, is it hot. He walks into the room.
As Charlie wearily enters.
How you been, buddy? He props the shotgun in a corner and sits facing Barton, stared at him.
...Don't look at me like that,  neighbor.  It's just me  Charlie.
I hear it's Mundt. Madman Mundt. Charlie reaches a flask from his pocket.
Jesus, people can be cruel... He takes a long draught from his flask, then gives a haun stare.
...if it's not my build, it's my  personality. Charlie is perspiring heavily. The fire rumbles in the  hallway.

...They say I'm a madman, Barton,  but I'm not mad at anyone. Honest  I'm not. Most guys I just feel sorry  for. Yeah. It tears me up inside, to  think about what they're going  through. How trapped they are. I  understand it. I feel for 'em. So I  try and help them out... He reached up to loosen his tie and pop his collar button

...Jesus. Yeah. I know what it feels  like, when things get all balled up  at the head office. It puts you  through hell, Barton. So I help people  out. I just wish someone would do as  much for me... He stares miserably down at his feet.
...Jesus it's hot. Sometimes it gets  so hot, I wanna crawl right out of  my skin. Self-pity:
But Charlie  why me? Why
Because you DON'T LISTEN! A tacky yellow fluid is dripping from Charlie's left ear running down his cheek.
...Jesus, I'm dripping again. He pulls some cotton from his pocket and plugs his ear.

...C'mon Barton, you think you know  about pain? You think I made your  life hell?  Take a look around this  dump. You're just a tourist with a  typewriter, Barton. I live here.  Don't you understand that... His voice is becoming choked.
...And you come into MY home... And  you complain that I'M making too...  much... noise. He looks up at Barton. There is a long silence. Finally:
...I'm sorry. Wearily:

Don't be. He rises to his feet and kneels in front of Barton at the foot of the bed. The two men regard each other. Charlie grabs two bars of the footboard frame, still star at Barton. His muscles tighten, though nothing moves. His neck fans with effort. All of his muscles tense.  His fac is a reddening grimace. With a shriek of protest, the metal gives. The bar to whi Barton is handcuffed had come loose at the top and Barton slides the cuff off it, free. Charlie gets to his feet.
I'm getting off the merry-go-round. He takes his shotgun and walks to the door.
...I'll be next door if you need me. A thought stops him at the door and he turns to face Bart Behind him the hallway blazes.
...Oh, I dropped in on your folks.  And Uncle Dave? He smiles. Barton looks at him dumbly.
...Good people. By the way, that  package I gave you? I lied. It isn't  mine. He leaves. Barton rises, picks up Charlie's parcel, and his script.
As Barton emerges. Flames lick the walls, causing the  wallpaper to run with the tack glue sap. Smoke fills the  hallway. Barton looks down the hall.

Charlie stands in front of the door to his room, his brie dangling from one hand, his other hand fumbling in his po for his key. With his hat pushed back on his head and his shoulders sl with fatigue, he could be any drummer returning to any ho after a long hard day on the road. He opens the door and goes into his room.
He turns and walks up the hallway, his script in one hand the parcel in the other. A horrible moaning sound  almost human  can be heard unde the roar of the fire.
We are tracking laterally across the lobby of an executiv building. From offscreen we hear:
Fink! Morris or Lillian Fink! Eighty-  five Fulton Street! Filtered through phone:
I understand that, sir
Or Uncle Dave! Our track has brought Barton into frame in the foreground unshaven, unkempt, bellowing into the telephone. In a hal in the background, a secretary gestures for Barton to hur up.
I understand that, sir, but there's  still no answer. Shall I check for  trouble on the line? Barton slams down the phone.
Barton enters, still clinging on to Charlie's parcel. Lou Breeze stands in one corner censoriously watching Bar Lipnik is at the far end of the room, gazing out the wind
Fink.
Mr. Lipnik.
Colonel Lipnik, if you don't mind. He turns to face Barton and we see that he is wearing a  smartly pressed uniform with a lot of fruit salad on the  chest.
...Siddown. Barton takes a seat facing Lipnik's desk.
...I was commissioned yesterday in  the Army Reserve. Henry Morgenthau  arranged it. He's a dear friend.
Congratulations.

Actually it hasn't officially gone  through yet. Had wardrobe whip this  up. You gotta pull teeth to get  anything done in this town. I can  understand a little red tape in  peacetime, but now it's all-out  warfare against the Japs. Little  yellow bastards.  They'd love to see  me sit this one out.
Yes sir, they
Anyway, I had Lou read your script  for me. He taps distastefully at the script on his desk, which ha slightly charred title page.
...I gotta tell you, Fink. It won't  wash.
With all due respect, sir, I think  it's the best work I've done.

Don't gas me, Fink. If you're opinion  mattered, then I guess I'd resign  and let YOU run the the studio. It  doesn't and you won't, and the  lunatics are not going to run THIS  particular asylum. So let's put a  stop to THAT rumor right now. Listlessly:
Yes sir.

I had to call Beery this morning,  let him know we were pushing the  picture back.  After all I'd told  him about quality, about that Barton  Fink feeling. How disappointed we  were. Wally was heartbroken. The man  was devastated. He was  well, I  didn't actually call him, Lou did.  But that's a fair description, isn't  it Lou?
Yes, Colonel.

Hell, I could take you through it  step by step, explain why your story  stinks, but I won't insult your  intelligence. Well all right, first  of all: This is a wrestling picture;  the audience wants to see action,  drama, wrestling, and plenty of it.  They don't wanna see a guy wrestling  with his soul  well, all right, a  little bit, for the critics  but  you make it the carrot that wags the  dog. Too much of it and they head  for exits and I don't blame 'em.   There's plenty of poetry right inside  that ring, Fink. Look at "Hell Ten  Feet Square".
"Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".

Look at "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".  These are big movies, Fink. About  big men, in tights  both physically  and mentally. But especially  physically. We don't put Wallace  Beery in some fruity movie about  suffering  I thought we were together  on that.
I'm sorry if I let you down.

You didn't let ME down. Or even Lou.  We don't live or die by what you  scribble, Fink. You let Ben Geisler  down. He liked you. Trusted you. And  that's why he's gone. Fired.  That  guy had a heart as big as the  outdoors, and you fucked him. He  tried to convince me to fire you  too, but that would be too easy. No,  you're under contract and you're  gonna stay that way.  Anything you  write will be the property of Capitol  Pictures. And Capitol Pictures will  not produce anything you write. Not  until you grow up a little. You ain't  no writer, Fink  you're a goddamn  write-off.
I tried to show you something  beautiful.  Something about all of
This sets Lipnik off:

You arrogant sonofabitch!  You think  you're the only writer who can give  me that Barton Fink feeling?!  I got  twenty writers under contract that I  can ask for a Finktype thing from.  You swell-headed hypocrite!  You  just don't get it, do you?  You think  the whole world revolves inside  whatever rattles inside that little  kike head of yours. Get him outta my  sight, Lou. Make sure he stays in  town, though; he's still under  contract. I want you in town, Fink,  and outta my sight. Now get lost.  There's a war on.
Crashing against the Pacific shore.
At midday, almost deserted. In the distance we see Barton walking. The paper-wrapped parcel swings from the twine in his lef hand.
He walks a few more paces and sits down on the sand, look out to see. His gaze shifts to one side.
Down the beach, a bathing beauty walks along the edge of water. She looks much like the picture on the wall in Bar hotel room.
He stares, transfixed, at the woman.
Very beautiful, backlit by the sun, approaching.
Following her with his eyes.
Her eyes meet Barton's. She says something, but her voice lost in the crash of the surf. Barton cups a hand to his ear.
I said it's a beautiful day...
Yes... It is...
What's in the box? Barton shrugs and shakes his head.
I don't know.
Isn't it yours?
I... I don't know... She nods and sits down on the sand several paces away fro him, facing the water but looking back over her shoulder Barton.
...You're very beautiful. Are you in  pictures? She laughs.
Don't be silly. She turns away to look out at the sea.

Facing the ocean. Barton sits in the middle foreground, b to us, the box in the sand next to him. The bathing beauty sits, back to us, in the middle backgr The surf pounds. The sun sparkles off the water.
